awd_titl_txt: Mentor-Connect: Leadership Development and Outreach for ATE-3

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Mentor-Connect: Leadership Development and Outreach for ATE-3 advanced technician education in new and proven ways by expanding the engagement of geographically and demographically diverse two-year colleges and STEM faculty in the ATE Program, stimulating use of ATE-developed resources, encouraging the submission of proposals by new and previous grantee institutions, and developing leaders and mentors among those who receive ATE funding. The project built on successes and lessons learned from previous Mentor-Connect projects and leveraged the work of other funded projects to build grant-writing capacity among 2-year colleges and thereby increase the number of ATE proposals submitted each year. Peer mentoring, instruction, and technical assistance have been used to teach grant writing and leadership skills through a construct of problem-based learning.

Intellectual Merit: Scholarship and leadership among two-year college STEM faculty have increased by providing instruction, technical assistance, and mentoring that enabled them to design technician education improvement projects and write competitive grant proposals to support implementation. The problem-based-learning construct of the Mentor-Connect model successfully engaged college teams in sustainable, faculty-lead improvement of technician education. Talent has been leveraged within the ATE Program, and both mentors and mentees have experienced leadership growth. M-C Forward has been led by highly experienced and successful ATE PIs and mentors who have effectively harnessed the collegial peer-sharing culture that exists within ATE, leveraged and extended the use of available NSF/ATE resources, and supported the involvement of new, diverse technician educators, defined and developed leadership skills for the advancement of technician education, and facilitated knowledge transfer from more to less experienced PIs. Mentor-Connect has established a unique, dynamic online repository of resources dedicated to supporting a better understanding of NSF funding requirements and ATE Program expectations and guiding competitive grant proposal development.

Broader Impacts: From inception, Mentor-Connect (M-C) projects (#1204463, #1501183, and #1840856) have focused on broadening the impact of the ATE Program. Mentor-Connect has become a model for using peer mentoring, technical assistance, and leadership development to build capacity at two-year colleges for developing competitive ATE proposals, securing NSF grants, and engaging STEM faculty often for the first time in these endeavors. Innovations and expanded Mentor-Connect services have steadily grown the program and increased participant success. Outcomes, resources, and strategies have been broadly shared through published articles, presentations, social media, and the project web site, www.Mentor-Connect.org. To date, Mentor-Connect has engaged more than 261 two-year colleges in 43 states and 2 US territories, 491 faculty, and 317 grant professionals and administrators in the ATE Program with a 72% average funding rate among participants over 11 annual Cohorts.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/19/2024
Modified by: Elaine L Craft
